query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Ora cen porta l’un de’ duri margini; 2 e ’l fummo del ruscel di sopra aduggia, 3 sì che dal foco salva l’acqua e li argini.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Now one of the hard banks bears us up; 2 and the smoke from the brook darkens above, 3 so that the water and the banks are saved from the fire.
**Old English:**
1 Nu us bær ðæs burnan stream 2 ofer ða deopan dene, 3 ðæt ðæs fyres blæst ne mæg 4 ða wæteru forswelgan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 Quali Fiamminghi tra Guizzante e Bruggia, 5 temendo ’l fiotto che ’nver’ lor s’avventa, 6 fanno lo schermo perché ’l mar si fuggia;
7 e quali Padoan lungo la Brenta, 8 per difender lor ville e lor castelli, 9 anzi che Carentana il caldo senta:
10 a tale imagine eran fatti quelli, 11 tutto che né sì alti né sì grossi, 12 qual che si fosse, lo maestro félli.
query.result:
**English:**
4 Like the Flemings between Wissant and Bruges, 5 fearing the flood that rushes toward them, 6 build a dike so that the sea may flee;
7 and like the Paduans along the Brenta, 8 to defend their towns and castles, 9 before the heat can be felt in Chiarentana:
10 in such a fashion were those [demons] made, 11 although neither so tall nor so large, 12 whatever they were, the master made them.
**Old English:**
4 Swa ða Flemisce be Guðlande and Biðlinde, 5 ðone flod forðredende ðe ofer hem feolled, 6 wyrcað ða weras wið ðæs wætres geweald 7 e ða Padƿan be Brentinga wic, 8 ða herewæðan ðe ðær wuniað, 9 ær ðon ðæt wæter Weonis gewunien:
10 swylce wæron ða ðe ðær wæron, 11 ðeah ðe hi ne wæron swa lange ne swa þicce, 12 swa hwæðere swa hi wæron, ða geworhte se wyrhta.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Già eravam da la selva rimossi 14 tanto, ch’i’ non avrei visto dov’ era, 15 perch’ io in dietro rivolto mi fossi,
16 quando incontrammo d’anime una schiera 17 che venian lungo l’argine, e ciascuna 18 ci riguardava come suol da sera
19 guardare uno altro sotto nuova luna; 20 e sì ver’ noi aguzzavan le ciglia 21 come ’l vecchio sartor fa ne la cruna.
query.result:
**English:**
13 We had already departed from the forest 14 so far that I would not have seen where it was, 15 even if I had turned back to look,
16 when we encountered a troop of spirits 17 who were coming along the bank, and each one 18 was looking at us as people are wont to do
19 in the evening when they look at each other under a new moon; 20 and they were squinting their eyes at us 21 like an old tailor does at the eye of a needle.
**Old English:**
13 We wæron ða of ðæm wudu afyrrede 14 swa feor ðæt ic ne mihte geseon hwar he wæs, 15 ðeah ðe ic me bæcling gewende,
16 ða ða we gemæton anne heap ðara sawla 17 ðe comon be ðæm ofre, and ælc 18 us beheold swa man deð on æfen
19 under niwan monan oðerne man; 20 and swa hi wrixledon heora eagan to us 21 swa ðe ealda snidræ to ðære nædle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Così adocchiato da cotal famiglia, 23 fui conosciuto da un, che mi prese 24 per lo lembo e gridò: «Qual maraviglia!».
query.result:
**English:**
22 Thus eyed by such a company, 23 I was recognized by one, who seized me 24 by the hem and cried out: "What a marvel!"
**Old English:**
22 Þus ymbþrungen mid ðære mænige, 23 ic wæs oncnawen fram anum ðara, 24 se ðe me nam be ðam læppe and clypode: "Hwæt is ðis wundor!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 E io, quando ’l suo braccio a me distese, 26 ficcaï li occhi per lo cotto aspetto, 27 sì che ’l viso abbrusciato non difese
28 la conoscenza süa al mio ’ntelletto; 29 e chinando la mano a la sua faccia, 30 rispuosi: «Siete voi qui, ser Brunetto?».
query.result:
**English:**
25 And I, when he stretched out his arm to me, 26 fixed my eyes on his baked appearance, 27 so that his scorched face did not prevent 28 my intellect from recognizing him; 29 and reaching out my hand to his face, 30 I answered: "Are you here, Ser Brunetto?"
**Old English:**
25 And ic, ða ða he his earm to me aræhte, 26 fæste mine eagan ðurh ðæt gecocede andwlætan, 27 swa ðæt ðæt ansyn abroden ne bewerode 28 ða gecneowlecan to minum mode; 29 and hnigan ða hand to his ansyne, 30 andswarode: "Sind ge her, la Ser Brunetto?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 E quelli: «O figliuol mio, non ti dispiaccia 32 se Brunetto Latino un poco teco 33 ritorna ’n dietro e lascia andar la traccia».
query.result:
**English:**
31 And he: "O my son, do not be displeased 32 if Brunetto Latino turns back a little with you 33 and lets the path go on."
**Old English:**
31 And he: "Eala, min sunu, ne beo ðe lað 32 gif Brunetto Latino lyt swigð mid ðe 33 and læt ðone stigol faran."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 I’ dissi lui: «Quanto posso, ven preco; 35 e se volete che con voi m’asseggia, 36 faròl, se piace a costui che vo seco».
query.result:
**English:**
34 I said to him: "As much as I can, come I pray; 35 and if you wish that I should sit with you, 36 I will do so, if it pleases him with whom I go."
**Old English:**
34 Ic cwæð to him: "Swa ic mæg, ic wille cuman; 35 and gif ðu wille ðæt ic mid ðe sitte, 36 ic ðæt do, gif him licað ðe ic mid fare."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 «O figliuol», disse, «qual di questa greggia 38 s’arresta punto, giace poi cent’ anni 39 sanz’ arrostarsi quando ’l foco il feggia.
query.result:
**English:**
37 "O son," he said, "whoever of this flock 38 stops for a moment, lies there for a hundred years 39 without turning over when the fire strikes him.
**Old English:**
37 "Eala, sunu," cwæð he, "hwa swa ðisse heorde 38 gestoð hwiltid, he ligeð ðonne hund gearena 39 unwendendlic, ðonne ðæt fyr hine gefeoð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Però va oltre: i’ ti verrò a’ panni; 41 e poi rigiugnerò la mia masnada, 42 che va piangendo i suoi etterni danni».
query.result:
**English:**
40 Therefore go on: I will come to you at the waters; 41 and then I will rejoin my company, 42 who go weeping for their eternal losses.
**Old English:**
40 Forðæm ga ofer: ic ðe wille cuman to ðæm wætere; 41 and ðonne eft cuman to minre menigeo, 42 ðe gað wepende hyra ecere yrmða.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Io non osava scender de la strada 44 per andar par di lui; ma ’l capo chino 45 tenea com’ uom che reverente vada.
query.result:
**English:**
43 I did not dare to descend from the road 44 to go along beside him; but I kept my head bowed 45 like a man who walks respectfully.
**Old English:**
43 Ic ne dorste of ðære stræte gangan 44 ðæt ic mid him on ða healfe eode; ac ic heafod min 45 heold swilce se ðe eawyrde wege gæð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 El cominciò: «Qual fortuna o destino 47 anzi l’ultimo dì qua giù ti mena? 48 e chi è questi che mostra ’l cammino?».
query.result:
**English:**
46 He began: "What fortune or destiny 47 before your final day brings you here below? 48 And who is this who shows you the way?"
**Old English:**
46 He ongan ða: "Hwat is ðin ærende, 47 ðe ðu ðus hrædlice hider becwome 48 ofer ðisne dimme dal? Hwa is se ðe ðe lædde?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 «Là sù di sopra, in la vita serena», 50 rispuos’ io lui, «mi smarri’ in una valle, 51 avanti che l’età mia fosse piena.
query.result:
**English:**
49 "Up there, in the serene life," 50 I answered him, "I lost my way in a valley, 51 before my age was full."
**Old English:**
49 "Þær ufan, on ðam sigewliðe," 50 ic him andswarode, "ic me fordemde on ðam dalum, 51 ær min aldor wæs orponcen."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Pur ier mattina le volsi le spalle: 53 questi m’apparve, tornand’ ïo in quella, 54 e reducemi a ca per questo calle».
query.result:
**English:**
52 Yet this morning I turned my back on them: 53 he appeared to me, as I was returning there, 54 and is leading me back home by this path."
**Old English:**
52 Þa gystran dæge ic him on bæc gewende: 53 he me eft ongen com, þa ic eft þanon gewende, 54 and me on þisne weg wisode."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Ma quello ingrato popolo maligno 62 che discese di Fiesole ab antico, 63 e tiene ancor del monte e del macigno,
64 ti si farà, per tuo ben far, nimico; 65 ed è ragion, ché tra li lazzi sorbi 66 si disconvien fruttare al dolce fico.
query.result:
**English:**
61 But that ungrateful and wicked people 62 who came down from Fiesole long ago, 63 and still holds the mountain and the stone,
64 will make itself your enemy because of your good deeds; 65 and it is right, because among the bitter sorbs 66 it is unfitting for the sweet fig to bear fruit.
**Old English:**
61 Ac ðæt unþancol folc and ðæt laðe 62 ðe of Fiosula æror niðer com, 63 and ðone munt and ðone stan hylt,
64 ðe bið ðin feond ðurh ðine welan; 65 and hit is riht, forðæm ðe ða bitran beorgas 66 ne geunnan ðæt ðær ðæt swete fic-appel weaxe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Vecchia fama nel mondo li chiama orbi; 68 gent’ è avara, invidiosa e superba: 69 dai lor costumi fa che tu ti forbi.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Ancient fame calls them blind in the world; 68 they are a miserly, envious, and proud people: 69 from their customs, see that you cleanse yourself.
**Old English:**
67 Ealde mærðe ða men nemnað blinde on worulde; 68 folc is gitsere, and aglæce, and ofermodig: 69 fram heora ðeawum do ðæt ðu ðe forðige.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 La tua fortuna tanto onor ti serba, 71 che l’una parte e l’altra avranno fame 72 di te; ma lungi fia dal becco l’erba.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Your fortune holds so much honor in store for you, 71 that both sides will hunger for you; 72 but the grass will be far from the beak.
**Old English:**
70 Þin hagosteald swa mycelne wurðscipe ðe sceal gehealdan, 71 ðæt ægðer gehwæðer ende ðinre æhta gyrneð; 72 ac hit bið ðæs gærses fram þæs nebban feor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Faccian le bestie fiesolane strame 74 di lor medesme, e non tocchin la pianta, 75 s’alcuna surge ancora in lor letame,
76 in cui riviva la sementa santa 77 di que’ Roman che vi rimaser quando 78 fu fatto il nido di malizia tanta».
query.result:
**English:**
73 Let the beasts of Fiesole make straw 74 of themselves, and not touch the plant, 75 if any still springs up in their dunghill,
76 in which the holy seed revives 77 of those Romans who remained there when 78 the nest of so much malice was made.
**Old English:**
73 Dō ðā Fiesolānīscan dēor dēaðlīce 74 hira sylfra, and ðā plante ne hrīnon, 75 gif ænig gīt in hira gāra wyxð,
76 on ðǣm ðæt hālga sǣd eft gelimpð 77 ðāra Rōmāna ðe ðær wunedon ðā 78 ðā wæs ðæs yfeles nest geworht swa micel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 «Se fosse tutto pieno il mio dimando», 80 rispuos’ io lui, «voi non sareste ancora 81 de l’umana natura posto in bando;
82 ché ’n la mente m’è fitta, e or m’accora, 83 la cara e buona imagine paterna 84 di voi quando nel mondo ad ora ad ora
85 m’insegnavate come l’uom s’etterna: 86 e quant’ io l’abbia in grado, mentr’ io vivo 87 convien che ne la mia lingua si scerna.
query.result:
**English:**
79 "If my request were fully granted," 80 I replied to him, "you would not yet be 81 banished from human nature;
82 for in my mind is fixed, and now pains me, 83 the dear and good paternal image 84 of you when in the world from time to time
85 you taught me how man makes himself eternal: 86 and how much I cherish it, while I live 87 it is fitting that my tongue should make known.
**Old English:**
79 "Gif min bøn wäre eal gefylled," 80 ic him andswarode, "þu nære næfre 81 of mannes cynne aworpen;
82 forðæm ðe on ðære heortan me is fæste, and nu me sargað, 83 ðin leofe and ðin gode fæderlice ansyn 84 ða ða ðu on worulde hwilum
85 lærdes ðu me hu man sceolde ðurhwunian: 86 and hu micel ic ðæt hæbbe on ðonce, ða hwile ðe ic lifge 87 gerisen is ðæt min tunge hit cyðe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Ciò che narrate di mio corso scrivo, 89 e serbolo a chiosar con altro testo 90 a donna che saprà, s’a lei arrivo.
query.result:
**English:**
88 What you narrate of my course I write, 89 and I save it to enclose with another text 90 for a lady who will know, if I reach her.
**Old English:**
88 Þæt ðu segst ðæt min ræd ic write, 89 and ic hit healde to belucan mid oðrum gewrite 90 ðære ðe hit cunnan wile, gif ic to hire cume.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Tanto vogl’ io che vi sia manifesto, 92 pur che mia coscïenza non mi garra, 93 ch’a la Fortuna, come vuol, son presto.
query.result:
**English:**
91 So much do I want you to know this, 92 as long as my conscience does not deceive me, 93 that I am ready for Fortune, as she wishes.
**Old English:**
91 Swa fela ic wille ðæt ðe sy geswutelod, 92 ðeah ðe min mod ne me lige, 93 ðæt ic eom gearu ðære Wyrd, swa heo wille.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Non è nuova a li orecchi miei tal arra: 95 però giri Fortuna la sua rota 96 come le piace, e ’l villan la sua marra».
query.result:
**English:**
94 Such a speech is not new to my ears: 95 therefore let Fortune turn her wheel 96 as she pleases, and the peasant his mattock.
**Old English:**
94 Nis ðeos spell me niwe to gehyranne: 95 forðy wendeð Fortunan hire hweol 96 swa swa hire licað, and ðe ceorl his sceare.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Lo mio maestro allora in su la gota 98 destra si volse in dietro e riguardommi; 99 poi disse: «Bene ascolta chi la nota».
query.result:
**English:**
97 My master then turned on his right cheek 98 and looked back at me; 99 then he said, "Listen well to whoever notes this."
**Old English:**
97 Min lareow ða on ða swiðran wang 98 wende hine and biheold me; 99 ða cwæð he: "Gehyr nu ða ðe ðis gehyrð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Né per tanto di men parlando vommi 101 con ser Brunetto, e dimando chi sono 102 li suoi compagni più noti e più sommi.
query.result:
**English:**
100 Nevertheless, I continue speaking with Ser Brunetto, and I ask who are 101 his most famous and greatest companions.
**Old English:**
100 Næs ðeah ðe læs ðe ic ðeah ða spræce 101 mid Ser Brunetto, and ic hine bæd ða 102 hwæt ða his gespelian mæste wæron and ða selestan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Ed elli a me: «Saper d’alcuno è buono; 104 de li altri fia laudabile tacerci, 105 ché ’l tempo saria corto a tanto suono.
query.result:
**English:**
103 And he said to me: "To know of some is good; 104 of the others it will be praiseworthy to be silent, 105 for time would be short for so much sound.
**Old English:**
103 And he sæde to me: "To witanne of sume is god; 104 of ðæm oðrum bið loflið to ðigienne, 105 forðæm ðe ðe tima bið sceort to swilcum hleopre.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 In somma sappi che tutti fur cherci 107 e litterati grandi e di gran fama, 108 d’un peccato medesmo al mondo lerci.
query.result:
**English:**
106 In short, know that all of them were clerics, 107 and great scholars of great renown, 108 sullied in the world by the same sin.
**Old English:**
106 On gesyne ðæt hi wæron ealle clercas, 107 and lareowas micle and mære, 108 and on worulde besmitene mid anum synne.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Priscian sen va con quella turba grama, 110 e Francesco d’Accorso anche; e vedervi, 111 s’avessi avuto di tal tigna brama,
112 colui potei che dal servo de’ servi 113 fu trasmutato d’Arno in Bacchiglione, 114 dove lasciò li mal protesi nervi.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Priscian goes with that wretched throng, 110 and Francesco d’Accorso too; and you could have seen them, 111 if you had had such a craving for that scab,
112 the one whom the servant of servants 113 transferred from the Arno to the Bacchiglione, 114 where he left his ill-stretched sinews.
**Old English:**
109 Priscianus gewat ða mid ðære grama heape, 110 and Franciscus Accursius eac; and ðu mihtest ðær geseon, 111 gif ðu hæfdest swylce wilnunge to ðære hreofle,
112 ðone ðe ðæs ðeowa ðeowa 113 awende of Arn ðurh Bacchiglione, 114 ðær he forlêt ða yfle atemede sinewa.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Di più direi; ma ’l venire e ’l sermone 116 più lungo esser non può, però ch’i’ veggio 117 là surger nuovo fummo del sabbione.
query.result:
**English:**
115 I would say more, but coming and speaking 116 can be no longer, because I see 117 new smoke rising there from the sand.
**Old English:**
115 Ic wolde mare secgan; ac ðæs cuman and ðæt sprecan 116 ne mæg leng ne beon, forðæm ic geseo 117 ðær niwe smeocan of ðæm sande arisan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Gente vien con la quale esser non deggio. 119 Sieti raccomandato il mio Tesoro, 120 nel qual io vivo ancora, e più non cheggio».
query.result:
**English:**
118 People come with whom I should not be. 119 May my Treasure be commended to you, 120 in which I still live, and I ask no more.
**Old English:**
118 Folc cymð mid ðæm ðe ic ne sceal wesan. 119 Sý min Goldhord ðe befæst, 120 on ðæm ic lybbe gýt, and ne bidde ic má.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Poi si rivolse, e parve di coloro 122 che corrono a Verona il drappo verde 123 per la campagna; e parve di costoro
124 quelli che vince, non colui che perde.
query.result:
**English:**
121 Then he turned around, and he seemed like one of those 122 who run for the green cloth in Verona 123 across the plain; and he seemed like one of those
124 who wins, not the one who loses.
**Old English:**
121 Þa he hine bewende, and he ðuhte ðara 122 ðe on ðære stræte æt Fearnum beoð 123 ofer ða feldas; and he ðuhte ðara
124 se ðe ðone sige hæfð, na se ðe ðone los forleoseð.
